thread.title: At Head of the Charles, boats worth $50,000 try not to crash - Massachusetts news
thread.title_full: At Head of the Charles, boats worth $50,000 try not to crash - Massachusetts news

author: boston.com
title: At Head of the Charles, boats worth $50,000 try not to crash - Massachusetts news
text:
A crew practices the approach to the Weeks Footbridge early in the morning on the Thursday before Head of the Charles. Photo by Charlotte Wilder If you want to see some action this weekend during the Head of the Charles Regatta, head to the Eliot Bridge. It’s close to the end of the race, so you’ll get to see exciting finishes. But it’s also notorious for boat crashes thanks to a precariously long curve in the river leading up to it.
“People do crash,” said Henry Palmer, head coach of the Union Boat Club. “They crash at the Eliot Bridge a fair bit because they get that turn wrong.”
The bridge connecting Fresh Pond Parkway to Storrow drive isn’t the only place where boats get into trouble on the 3-mile-long course. The Weeks Footbridge and the Larz Anderson bridges also give rowers a hard time.
“If you look at a map, it’s an S—you turn one way quickly and less than 100 meters later, you’re turning the other way, and people get jammed up,” Palmer said.
The most offending bridges. Google Maps You might be thinking that by “expensive,” we’re talking somewhere in the ballpark of a couple thousand dollars, right? Not so much. A boat that seats eight people can cost in the neighborhood of $50,000. The price tag on a a nice single can run around $14,000.
“They’re expensive toys,” Palmer said. “Buying a racing single is a bit like buying a top-end road bike. You go, ‘Holy s---, these are expensive!’ It’s largely why masters rowing is very big, because it’s old gentlemen with fancy equipment floating down the river. They love it.”
Fortunately, it’s usually not a sunk cost when boats collide with each other or large structures. Palmer explained that it’s usually the oars that suffer the most in a crash. If the boats do get damaged in a collision, the damage is usually easily repairable.
The most dangerous time for a boat, it turns out, is actually when it’s being transported from race to race.
“There was a case a few years ago where a tree fell and landed on trailer and smashed all the boats,” Palmer said.
The key takeaway here? Watch where you’re going, and don’t park your rig carrying hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of boats underneath a tree.
